learning_outcomes.description: Recognise, categorise and describe biological agents that constitute hazards, and the context of their threat risk.

Individually build upon and re-apply your knowledge and skills in discipline areas such as epidemiology, infectious diseases, plant and animal biosciences to help understand and mitigate biosecurity threats
Describe, and manage scenarios within, biosecurity regulatory and operational frameworks.

Working as part of a team and individually apply specific skills (e.g. risk assessment, biosecurity auditing) in managing and communicating biosecurity hazards at international, national and local levels.

assessments.weighting: <dd>40% Each test will contribute 20% to your final mark </dd>
assessments.task_description:
This is a sequential assessment item undertaken as an online, time-limited activity. It will be completed during scheduled classroom sessions in Weeks 5 and 12, between 11:00 am and 12:00 pm. Students must attend the classroom in person for this assessment, and their student ID will be checked.

The first online test will cover Modules 1–3, including:

Module 1: Introduction to Biosecurity

Module 2: Biosecurity Regulations

Module 3: Biosecurity Threats

The second online test will take place in Week 12 during class time and will cover Modules 4–6, including:

Module 4: On-farm Biosecurity

Module 5: Biosecurity Monitoring

Module 6: Biosecurity Risk and Outbreak Management

Each online test will consist of multiple-choice questions and will contribute 20% to your final mark. You will have 60 minutes to complete each test.

Additional details will be provided on the course Blackboard site.
assessments.submission_guidelines: These online tests will be conducted using Inspera. To familiarise yourself with Inspera and the Safe Exam Browser, please visit the links below:
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Students will work individually or in groups during each tutorial session, engaging in scenario-based tasks and field activities. Each student must submit their tutorial sheets individually, and the final report will be recorded via Blackboard, with individual marks assigned accordingly. This assessment task is worth 25% of the final grade and will be evaluated using the rubric published on the course Blackboard site, with all rubric criteria assessed individually.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students will collaborate in groups of 3–4 to design and deliver a 15–20-minute educational session tailored for high school students. The session may take the form of a seminar, classroom activity, or engaging presentation. The objective is to choose a significant biosecurity topic and create an informative, engaging session aimed at raising awareness and improving understanding of biosecurity issues.

Groups and topics will be established by the end of week 3 of the semester. This task promotes teamwork, creativity, and the ability to communicate complex ideas effectively to a younger audience, while also building advocacy skills and promoting public engagement. While students are required to work as a team, each member must present for at least five minutes and contribute meaningfully to the development of PowerPoint slides or classroom activities.

Assessment will be based on individual performance, including both the presentation and the contribution to the learning materials. The presentations are planned to take place at a high school in the Gatton area during Weeks 11–13. Each group will be randomly assigned a presentation date within this period. Presentation materials (e.g., slides, activity plans) must be submitted to Blackboard by the due date.

Additionally, students must submit recorded videos of their presentations within 24hr of their scheduled presentation day via Blackboard. The assessment task aligns perfectly with Queensland and national biosecurity strategic plans, highlighting education, awareness, and community involvement as essential pillars for strengthening biosecurity resilience.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submissions independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit your Assessment through the course Turnitin submission point in Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
15/04/2026 4:00 pm

Participation is compulsory with questions submitted and evaluated on a Pass or Fail basis.
assessments.task_description:
An Industry Expert Panel Discussion will be held in Week 7, on 15 April 2026. Invited guests from industry and government will explore one of the emerging challenges in biosecurity and its real-world applications within the course content. During the panel discussion and Q&A session, students are expected to actively engage with panel members and ask insightful questions. This will be graded on a pass or fail basis, assessed on the relevance and thoughtfulness of the question. The topic will be announced in advance to allow students to study and research the subject thoroughly. Students will need to submit their questions via Padlet 2 days before the session. Submitted questions will be evaluated based on their relevance to the announced topic, the depth of understanding demonstrated, and their connection to course content or real-world biosecurity issues.

This session is designed as a live, in-person tutorial, and we strongly encourage all students to attend on campus, with the opportunity to interact with panel members and learn about the latest technology in biosecurity. Attending in person provides the added benefit of networking with the panel members during an informal discussion at the conclusion of the event. For those unable to attend, the session will be streamed live on Zoom and recorded as a backup.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Upload your questions to Padlet. The link will be provided by the course staff by the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture Series

Lectures are delivered by UQ staff and invited specialists from industry and government. Some content is provided as pre-recorded segments that students can access flexibly to support preparation and revision. The lecture program is organised into seven modules:

  1. Introduction to Biosecurity
  2. Biosecurity Regulations
  3. Biosecurity Threats
  4. On-farm Biosecurity
  5. Biosecurity Monitoring
  6. Biosecurity Risk and Outbreak Management
  7. Emerging Topics in Biosecurity

We strongly encourage students to attend lectures in person whenever possible. Face-to-face attendance supports active participation, discussion, and immediate feedback, and it provides valuable opportunities to engage with guest speakers from industry and government and to connect with peers.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture Series Lectures are delivered by UQ staff and invited specialists from industry and government. Some content is provided as pre-recorded segments that students can access flexibly to support preparation and revision. The lecture program is organised into seven modules: Introduction to Biosecurity Biosecurity Regulations Biosecurity Threats On-farm Biosecurity Biosecurity Monitoring Biosecurity Risk and Outbreak Management Emerging Topics in Biosecurity We strongly encourage students to attend lectures in person whenever possible. Face-to-face attendance supports active participation, discussion, and immediate feedback, and it provides valuable opportunities to engage with guest speakers from industry and government and to connect with peers.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorials and Practice-Based Learning

Tutorials are designed to help students apply course concepts to practical biosecurity problems. Across the semester, students will work through activities that build their ability to interpret biosecurity regulations, explain the impacts of biosecurity threats, plan and critique outbreak investigations, and conduct basic risk assessments using real or simulated scenarios. These sessions support students to move from understanding core principles to making defensible decisions in realistic biosecurity contexts.

One tutorial will be delivered as a panel discussion with invited guests from industry and government. The purpose of this session is to connect course content with current, real-world biosecurity challenges, including how decisions are made in practice, what constraints agencies and industry face, and how emerging technologies are changing surveillance, diagnostics, and response. Students are expected to engage actively in the panel discussion and Q and A by asking relevant, thoughtful questions that demonstrate preparation and an ability to link the topic to course concepts. The panel topic will be announced in advance, allowing students to read, reflect, and research the issue. Students will submit their questions via Padlet, with instructions provided beforehand, at least two days before the session.

Following the panel, students will consolidate their learning by producing a short written reflection that summarises key insights from the discussion and links them to course concepts and real world biosecurity practice. This activity is intended to strengthen students’ ability to synthesise information from expert perspectives, identify implications for policy and practice, and communicate their understanding clearly.

This panel tutorial is designed as a live, in-person session, and students are strongly encouraged to attend on campus to maximise interaction with the panel members and benefit from informal networking at the conclusion of the event. For students who cannot attend in person, the session will be streamed live via Zoom and recorded as a backup.

In addition to face to face tutorials, students will deepen their understanding through an online module offered by Animal Health Australia or Plant Health Australia. These modules provide a solid foundation in national and international emergency disease management, including governance arrangements, surveillance and reporting pathways, preparedness planning, and response principles. Students must complete either the Emergency Animal Disease module or the Emergency Plant Disease module. A completion certificate must be uploaded via Blackboard as evidence of completion.

Note: Class time has been allocated to complete this task in Week 1. Uploading this certificate via Turnitin by the end of teaching Week 13 is required to complete the tutorial assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Group Seminars: Student-Led Learning

Student seminars (Weeks 12–13) provide an opportunity for students to learn from each other and to practise communicating biosecurity concepts to a wider audience. Working in groups, students will research a selected biosecurity topic, develop engaging learning materials, and deliver a short seminar to the class.

These sessions are designed to strengthen students’ skills in teamwork, critical reading, synthesis of evidence, and clear scientific communication. They also create a structured peer-learning environment where students are encouraged to attend all seminars, participate actively, ask thoughtful questions, and reflect on how different biosecurity issues connect across animal, plant, and environmental contexts.
